review: I've owned the Apple TV for some time now. I was disappointed that rumours of apps and games never came to fruition, but the full price Fire TV wasn't compelling enough to upgrade.When the Fire TV Stick was offered for $19, I leaped as I thought this was my in. Alas, even at $39, you aren't getting any kind of deal. Here's why:1. Everything is very, very cheaply constructed. The remote creaks and distorts under normal usage, which you might write off as it's a free remote with a cheap streaming box, but the game controller - an additional $50-60 purchase - is just as cheaply made. Amazon do not care about hardware quality.2. You will notice how cheap the remote is because you will be using it a lot to navigate the software's confusing menu system. The Apple TV may not have the apps and games, but it is way less confusing to navigate and behaves in logical ways. Voice search eases this, but you either have to buy an extra, enhanced remote with the feature, or use an app on a phone or tablet.3. 99% of the games are terrible. Besides (25+ year old games featuring) Sonic The Hedgehog, it is mostly cheap crapware knocked out by a sub-par hobbyist in his basement.4. 99% of the apps are terrible, and because Amazon quite clearly favour their own Prime ecosystem, they're harder to use than they need be. On Apple TV, Hulu Plus and Netflix and all the other alternative video services get equal billing with the iTunes store fronts.I really can't recommend this device. If you are all in with Prime Video and Music, get the regular Fire TV. But only if. The Roku range and Apple TV are otherwise vastly superior.
